tn.text: A new poem begins. The writer of Lamentations uses many different ways to express that the people of Israel have lost God's favor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] ​and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Possible meanings are 1) God is threatening to harm the people of Jerusalem or 2) God has already harmed the people (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]).

tn.ref: daughter of Zion ... daughter of Judah
tn.text: These are poetic names for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: He has thrown the splendor of Israel down from heaven to earth
tn.text: "Jerusalem has lost all favor with the Lord" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]).
"disregarded," "paid no attention to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]).

Here "footstool" represents the place where God acts kindly enough to be present. Possible referents here are 1) "his beloved city of Jerusalem" or 2) "his covenant with Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]).
a general period of time, not one 24-hour day AT: "at the time when he displayed his anger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"completely destroyed" like an animal leaves nothing when he swallows food (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the fortified cities of the daughter of Judah
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) the fortified cities throughout Judah, or 2) the fortified walls of Jerusalem.
The writer continues the use of metaphors to express God's opposition to Judah.

tn.ref: he has cut off every horn of Israel
tn.text: Here "horn" (that is, an animal horn) stands for "strength." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"stopped protecting us from our enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: he has bent his bow toward us
tn.text: A soldier had to bend his bow in order to shoot it. AT: "He has made his bow ready to shoot us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: tent of the daughter of Zion
tn.text: AT: "the people's homes in Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
These is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: poured out his wrath like fire
tn.text: "shown how angry he is by destroying everything like a person setting fires would" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:lam:02:01|2:2]].

tn.ref: He has increased mourning and lamentation
tn.text: AT: "He has caused more and more people to mourn and lament"
This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_Personification]])
a very small building for holding farming tools or for sheltering someone who is guarding a garden

tn.ref: caused both solemn assembly and Sabbath to be forgotten in Zion
tn.text: AT: "caused the people in Zion to forget both solemn assembly and Sabbath" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: He has given over ... into the hand of the enemy
tn.text: "He has turned over ... to the enemy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the word "her" may refer either to Jerusalem or to the temple. Possible translations are 1) "the walls of Jerusalem's palaces" or 2) "the walls of the temple."

tn.ref: They have raised a shout in the house of Yahweh, as on the day of an appointed feast
tn.text: This is an ironic comparison between the happy, noisy festivals of Israel and the loud shouts of victory of the Babylonians. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: He has stretched out the measuring line
tn.text: AT: "He has measured the length of the wall" so he knows exactly how much to destroy (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: has not withheld his hand from destroying
tn.text: AT: "He has destroyed using all his power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
"kept his hand to himself"

tn.ref: He has made the ramparts and wall to lament; together they wasted away
tn.text: "Because he has destroyed the ramparts and walls, they look like people who lament and have lost their strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Ancient cities had a main "wall" to keep attackers out, and an outer line of "ramparts" to keep attackers from the wall.
This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
to show they were mourning (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The writer shifts from describing Jerusalem to describing his own experience.

tn.ref: My eyes have failed from their tears
tn.text: AT: "I have cried until I cannot cry anymore" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: my inner parts are poured out to the ground
tn.text: AT: "my entire inner being is in grief" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: because of the destruction of the daughter of my people
tn.text: "the daughter of my people" is a poetic name of Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. AT: "because my people have been crushed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

The phrase "grain and wine" is a common way of saying "food and drink." AT: "Give us something to eat and drink." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The writer begins to address Jerusalem.
"There is nothing that I can say ... Jerusalem." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: To what can I compare to you ... Zion?
tn.text: "There is nothing to which I can compare you ... Zion." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"No one can heal you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: clap their hands ... hiss and shake their heads
tn.text: ways in which people make fun of others and insult them (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Is this the city that they called 'The Perfection of Beauty,' 'The Joy for All of Earth'?
tn.text: This question is used to express sarcasm." This city that they called 'The Perfection of Beauty,' 'The Joy for All of Earth' is not so beautiful or joyful any more!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"We have completely destroyed Jerusalem" like an animal swallows its food (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: he has lifted up the horn of your enemies
tn.text: Here "horn" (that is, an animal horn) often stands for strength. AT: "he has increased the power of your enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Possible meanings are 1) "The people of Jerusalem shout from their innermost being" or 2) the speaker wants the walls to shout to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: walls of the daughter of Zion ... of every street
tn.text: The writer speaks to the walls of Jerusalem. He wants the people of Jerusalem to do what he is telling the walls to do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Make your tears flow down like a river
tn.text: "Cry many tears" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"all of the time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
"Do not allow yourself to rest"

tn.ref: at the beginning of the night watches
tn.text: "many times during the night" that is, every time a watchman comes on duty
This was an action often performed while praying.

tn.ref: at the corner of every street
tn.text: "where the streets come together" or "by the roads"

tn.ref: Should women eat the fruit of their wombs ... for?
tn.text: AT: "Woman should not eat their own children ... for!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"children who are still young" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
the weakest and strongest of adults (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
"the attackers I was afraid of" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: as you would call the people to a feast day
tn.text: "as if they were coming to a feast" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
